text: this is the link for the actual updated information for pui definition. your links sent me around the block to get there. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/clinical-criteria.html?cdc_aa_refval=https%3a%2f%2fwww.cdc.gov%2fcoronavirus%2f2019-ncov%2fclinical-criteria.html
good luck! i tried to give a practice presentation after supper the other week, and when they are mobile, they just get up and leave the table! gotta up the entertainment for teen boys!!

i wondered! it was hilarious, and the students loved it....so good learning? and really, how many amorphous different colored blobs and pac men can you put into a signal transduction pathway- gotta spice it up somehow!

sooooo funny. immunology class, tcr signal transduction pathway: show animation from janeway text to class to get ready to draw out. someone did not ask teen boys when they designed the shapes of the molecules! slp-76 is excited to be a part of it!

uggh! like our students are not stressed enough? there are faculty that also say they have to have a publication to get in. i mean, yes, helpful to have all as & research pubs, but by no means required! do well, be well rounded, be compassionate & show you care in words and deeds

my guy played a master class for jonah kim yesterday, as part of festival mozaic, & i can't stop thinking about what a brave musician and human he is!! he's an introverted perfectionist (kinda like his mamma) so it's tough to put himself out there, but he was amazing!
sending the strength of beautiful mountains... best wishes your way!!

barrier alert!! md will only allow psych techs & np to dispense naloxone- so the person doing the trainings (100s of them at this point) often has to refer folks to another place/time to get their naloxone kit. we found an underground work around, but ridiculous shitty policy.
i talked to my immunology class about "be the match" and bone marrow/stem cell donation. several students said they would sign up!
this kind of shit is what keeps me up at night....ugh- so ignorant.
i know!!! so cute! and also, i'm so glad to be home getting comfy and ready to snuggle up with my guys. everyone has their fantasy dates! :-)
i was just at pre vd happy hour with friends, and there was a young woman in a full red gown. never have i ever made that much effort for a date....impressive and sweet!
and one student included this at the bottom of her notes from the talk- happy to be bringing awareness (and more naloxone) out in the world!

someone did take a dose of nasal naloxone out of one of the kits we passed around (hopefully b/c they needed it!) - and also hope folks got message that we can provide a kit to anyone who wants it! just let us know!

co-presentation at calpolyteachin on our overdose prevention/naloxone distribution program in the county jail. students excited to hear from jail md, but highlight was hearing from other student and alumni volunteers who do the trainings!

so many times. weekly. living up to the scattered prof stereotype. weirdly, in our dept every faculty has "master" key that unlocks all of our offices. so i can ask a different colleague each week. handy! front desk person hands me keys before i even open my mouth. embarrassing.
what company do you use? is the price comparable? i hope we are done waaaay ahead of time, but you know how it goes!

fabric posters for conference presentation?? did i hallucinate this ? did you like them? i have students traveling to nm for a conference next month and was curious! would love to avoid the poster tube....
preach.
thanks! so helpful!

thanks! i have a couple of student/volunteer/data wranglers doing just that (at least the numbers part). but unless i stay on top of it w/reminders, we get behind. just too many fires to put out, you know? it does make me appreciate funders who give more/ask less & trust us.

so much this. and i wish i had it in me to totally blow it off, or just completely copy/paste it. ugh. i highly doubt anyone looks at it. but they did bother to send me a e mail reminder 2 days before it was due....so.

i'm writing a mid-year report for an $1800 grant for the sep. they also (of course) also require an end of the year report. i am trying (unsuccessfully) to not feel resentful about this. we need every dollar, but jeez this is a ridiculous amount of busy work for the payout.

for me, the year before- trying to get paper submitted, write grants, prep class & care for young kids. we sacrificed $to hire nanny, then she quit (preggo) & my husband & i came as close as ever have to divorce. sorry not more positive-it's been better since!
not necessary for abstract, usually not enough words to spare anyway, if you're like me! :-)

at a cafe reading about health care access for my service learning class, waiting for youth symphony rehearsal to finish. two older ladies are *loudly* arguing about whether yoga promotes the devil...& i can't stop listening. (i need sound blocking headphones!) help!

yep. and folks who really *should* know better perpetuate it. mds, ph folks etc. this one, and the touch/inhale fentanyl and you od myth are everywhere, and they do real harm. ugh. go forth and debunk good people.

ugh. this particular myth is so pervasive.... folks in my county all congratulating (themselves, mostly) about prescription rates going down, wondering why overdoses continue.....and increase. thanks for your work!

played cello in vivaldi’s 4 seasons w slo chamber orchestra today and this random handsome dude was playing in the bass section!! super fun! families that play music together....get great snacks on the way home!
my community orchestra is playing all four of vivaldi's four seasons tomorrow! come join us for the lovely music, and yummy (performer provided) snacks at intermission!
super shero! i am taking care of past tuesday me on fri. afternoon....and past me can eff off.
listening to my 12yo practice allegro appassionato getting ready for a master class next month. hard work, not easy.... i'm proud of him!!

"it’s 2020. be bold or get the hell out of the way" needed this today! especially for academia- "the harmfulness of our propensity to intellectualize is only matched by our delusion that we’re making progress through intellectualization".
some of our peeps at the sep love those- they don't carry many, but easy to stash! i want some of those rainbow stickers!! so cute!

ugh- that weird stupid guilt anxiety is so messed up! being with your new baby & partner, bonding & giving care are so important!! our priorities in this country are ass backwards, and i hope we can change in my lifetime! congrats and enjoy the snuggles....
amazing people and inspiring messages....wmslo womensmarch2020

sexism/misogyny seems to be everywhere based on national politics. though it is a bit shocking to hear your small-ish town mayor interviewed by scott simon! makes me angry-but i think there are more of us than there are of them. at least- i'm going to the women's march today!
tfw your husband gets called back to work at 10pm just as you are finishing writing a quiz for your 7am class.....making him coffee and looking forward to bed, but a little sad....

i mean, the wording was so off-putting and stilted! and i've written hundreds (and hundreds!) of letters and have never seen this category! i get the concern and talk with my students about that when they represent the university... but just seemed weird in this context!

finishing some letters of rec one application had checklist for appearance: -unusually well-groomed -well-groomed on most occasions -acceptable, average -rather poor impression -untidy appearance a possible handicap -no basis to judge wtf???? well-groomed? are they dogs??
yes! especially when coupled with the excellent "your own backyard" podcast by chris lambert. fully creeped out.
yep! i hold a long grudge. my parents actually chose candace with an *a*, b/c they thought candi/candy less likely. ha. nice to "meet" another- there are few these days!
same- except candace, not candice (or weirdly- candance-i can't!) only pe teachers called me candy- even after i said no. still makes me shudder.

yes, we are so happy to make some forward progress. maybe am doing this backwards- find provider for telemedicine first, then ehr? just requested a quote from dr chrono, another nonprofit in town uses that one.

yes, it's ridiculous. but we luckily manage ok- i'm afraid for when my kids go to college- but by then will just rent rooms out to poly students!! it's beautiful here, & we do need mds something fierce! (thus the turn towards telemedicine)so lmk if you change your mind! :-)
no, that's the unicorn we are looking for.... :-) . the grant is from the state and managed through the county ph dept., so they have a med director (obviously), but we are not under her direction.
awesome, thanks for the info! clinic will be in slo- so far have rn for blood draws and labs covered- working on next steps from there!
nope! i'm an academic (non clinician) and we are just getting set up- so sort of steepish learning curve!

finally expanding hcv linkage to care at our sep! it's been our dream! questions re. easy/cheap ehr to use, and any contacts for and/or logistical issues we should consider to set up telemedicine to get folks treated.....
little extra caffeine for my afternoon syllabi prep- harm reduction mug courtesy of  and cutest mana-tea infuser from my sister!
happy birthday! great place to spend it! sorry about bronchitis-my 12yo finally slowed down after ~35d. of cough. it's exhausting.
same! i got for holiday gifts, and am wearing one- our sep site manager and collaborator as well! will definitely get more for gifts in the future!
satsuma, popcorn and half a toblerone.... went to the gym, but not b/c resolution, b/c of mental health needs....

having experienced/observed unconscious bias in exactly this way in academia, this is sadly not surprising. seeming small slights compound to a larger problem. evaluating unconscious bias: speaker introductions at an international oncology conference

especially: "if you find yourself having to apologize or restate things, it’s not a sign that you’re a horrible or bigoted person...it means you’re challenging yourself in important ways. you should be proud of that. and grateful to the people who are helping challenge you."
gratitude for this thoughtful writing, posting for my students (and me!) under discussion guidelines for my service learning class: responding to call-outs with wisdom and grace by
made tempeh garlic lime lettuce wraps for supper, and husband + 16 yo had chili dogs instead...the force is balanced in our house! they were delish and 12yo loved them! all are happy!
one hiv specialist md in county only has clinic hours on one day a week- it's pretty typical. they were told by friends to go to her, didn't realize could go elsewhere. so awful.
happy harm reduction holidays! thanks for helping w my holiday shopping  love this mug, and will meet people where they are at w syringes, narcan and hot cocoa!

totally agree with all. we took this hard, but the sad fact is our community makes it hard to navigate for the already marginalized especially. everyone walking thru the sep doors has to fight stigma constantly. let's decriminalize hiv & end the drug war too, how about?!
yes! we are lucky this will happen in ca soon!

yep. folks coming to us at sep have a ton of different barriers to access care-we need to do a better job of making sure they know what is out there/where to get it, and then help them link up if they want. we are small & only open a few hours a week, but we need to do better.

no one should get hiv, regardless of how promiscuous they are (which is their business), & especially not when we have relatively easy prevention. this person was absolutely devastated. it highlighted for me need to spread awareness & enhance collaborations w med community.

yep. we () let them down by not having info more prominent re where to get prep w/o waiting, & also exposes lack of enough folks engaged in prev/treatment of hiv in our community. i feel sick/sad. next year will be better b/c no script required, but that doesn't help them.

that's awesome! we should survey the eds here (ca) to see if they will do this! this was not me, but a sep participant who came in for test while waiting for prep. highlighted need for better info to our folks re where to go while waiting, and to find more collaborators!
i'm so sorry. thank you for the work you do.

it really is. stopped me in my tracks several times the last few days. what are we even doing? literally makes me want to call every flipping md in the county to appeal directly for help. same story w/hcv. need $, but also more support from med and public health community

100% endorse. it's too late for this person, but it highlighted the urgency for me- even as an organization we (the sep) face many barriers to what we can provide based on who will work with us and $. we gotta step it up- hopeful that the ca law will truly help.

devastating story: a person in our community waiting over 3 months for appt to get prep, but instead tested positive for hiv. negative when they got on the wait list to see doc. it's infuriating & deeply sad. as a non md/np, makes me feel helpless. we have to do better.

no- yikes! i did let me 8am lab (all graduating in 4 weeks) make pancakes on a griddle in the hallway- which set off the fire alarms and caused the building(s) to evacuate. bike cop was not amused, but other campus cop had a pancake with us once we moved to the patio.....

first post-grades e-mail! a good one! "i wanted to say thank you for an amazing class. med mcro challenged me but i truly enjoyed it.there is no other class i would have enjoyed :40am...& some exciting news. an email from ucxx officially inviting me to ’recruitment day’!"

grades are in!!!!!!! hectic quarter with sweet/smart students- loads of fun... but ready for a break and some holiday cheer! hoping my immune system fights off the cold from hell (flu?) from the rest of my family...so we can celebrate together!

b/c of the necessity for local gvmt to authorize & then can set parameters. county officials & leo mostly do not care about best practice, just about doing enough to look good. outsized fear of discarded rigs, not enough care re actually preventing hcv/hiv. super frustrating.

i'm so sorry! last year i was working on grant report due.... of course, on dec. 31. after getting an e mail from the funding agency mid dec saying effectively "sorry our on-line submission program sucks, save your work often, good luck, we are out of office until jan 6."

knight lab (grad school) reunion in chicago... so sweet to reconnect and express gratitude to some folks who were instrumental in me getting my ph.d. (pi-chen, mae, setu), & swap stories with the new(er) folks including the first undergrad i sent to loyola (pehga)!
thanks for the reminder to donate!
enjoy- you've earned it!!
that was a brave choice! lots of shifting and no place to hide! i was impressed with the class, they were into it!
great job!! arioso?

awww! i'm sure they loved it! i play cello too! my 12 yo plays cello, and 15yo plays bass! it's so fun to bring music into their lives! good job!! (and i'm more nervous playing cello duets w/ my son on his recitals than i ever was playing my own in college!)
well i almost put whipped cream on top too...
grading....

you are welcome! we super love it! our volunteers made their own video to use in the jail (b/c we needed it to be locally specific and have our info in it)- they did a great job too, but it's no where near as personal & sweet.

the training materials tab on our sep's slack page! ha ha. i have new folks go through the webinars on hrc website; we watch od education naloxone videos  has our current fav; & tons of helpful info https://filtermag.org/amp/ plus crackdown and
wha.......??? i almost feel sorry for them- except more sorry for their students! plus, so aggressive, who does that??!
also sending gratitude to the paramedic who called public health to let us know. we appreciate the effort and support!!

one of our sep participants just reversed an overdose w/naloxone at a local shelter! strong/hard work saving lives- am so proud of all of our folks for being willing to step up and take care of our community.

taking my coughing up a lung kiddo to work today- too much coughing for school, but can't miss my second to last lab of quarter. i don't think he's contagious, but will "store" him in the prep area w/computer, tea, soup and blankie. parenting....

i'm so so sorry. my 12yo is only on day 9 of coughing non stop (and vomiting from coughing) and i can't imagine a month. i hope you feel better soon!!! at least in time for a real holiday break and to enjoy your new place!
finished this batch of letters of rec (for now!)! here's a picture of the grand canyon at sunrise we took this week to celebrate!
my 12yo just played cribbage for like 3 hours with his great-uncle dick.....i'm in awe. (and awww) also, holy shit i watched for an hour and i *still* don't really get it!

it was amazing, and sedona is so pretty! poor bodhi is coughing so much, and it was like 15 deg. at sunrise, so we were mellow. i did see some very clueless folks asking questions at ranger station wanting to hike down and back today- i always wonder what happens!!
then made sedona by sunset....
for real for real!! we were there yesterday! bodhi has a bad cold, so we did not camp or hike too much, just enjoyed the views. here's a pic from our sunrise walk.

these stories are so infuriating. people and orgs reaching the most vulnerable should be supported with $, & given awards for the work they do! instead they are stigmatized and starved of resources- and we know damn well the hd is not serving the same folks. it's gross.
thankful for nonprofits—as vital, invisible, and underappreciated as air
congratulations! that's amazing, and stressful to go thru! we just bought our first (ever) place over a year ago and i'm still not over the trauma of looking. yay!!

i'm not sure why this reminded me of the vendo-muck machine at loyola in grad school that would dispense "cafe mocha" into weird paper cups with playing card symbols on them.... i lived off that shit during time course late night pipette fests.

it's such good discipline for kids! and honestly, it's the only other language i'm fluent in and can share with them. it helped my older (hs aged) son when one of my college students told him how cool girls think you are if you play an instrument. whatever works?! :-)

sometimes it feels like too much, & i did quit for 10 yrs when i had babies & was an assist prof. right now we're playing all 4 of the 4 seasons- they start to run together into vivaldi mush at 9:30pm in rehearsal. but worth it! you will get back to it someday!!

wow! that's amazing! agree re. mediation- bach cello suites are therapy for me. my younger son also plays cello, he's just at the age to start bach, he did the minuets from the 1st suite so far- it's way harder than it sounds. especially if you can hear how it's supposed to be.

ah, horn player!! you all are amazing! of course you love the russians. i love love love the hippo bass reference as a cellist, & mother of a teen who plays bass- he is currently working on the elefant's gavotte (a drunken version of saint-saens elephant from carnival)

that sorta hilarious, sorta strange/inappropriate. i can't imagine!! was it "normal" behavior for him or r&j just got him in the mood? what is your instrument?? i play cello in a community orchestra and we just did romeo and juliet- it's quite a workout!

the misuses of “biological sex” "biological factors hold appeal and power since reference to “biology” and “science” lends any suggested trait or combination of traits the appearance of neutrality and thus objectivity."
i was just in chicago giving an alumni talk at loyola, and passed out these stickers and buttons. everyone loved them and wanted to know where to get....it's such an enjoyable word to spread!

cal poly bio alum, former sep and americorps volunteer spreading the harm reduction love in med. school- helped train 179 students and faculty in overdose prevention and naloxone administration!! go nick- you do us proud!!
not loving this situation....probably a prank but i really really *hate* that this happens and we have to take seriously.

i, like many faculty, keep a folder of special student e-mails and notes to read when i'm down- i love this idea of paying it forward. i think whenever i read a few, i should send a note letting them know their words make a difference to me.
what a sweet gesture! a beautiful reminder to take every opportunity to inspire and build each other up.
same, same. ask my (actual) kids. i'm officially in the "can't use new slang or kids will die of embarrassment" stage of parenting.
what?? that's a great word! let's bring it back!!
it's a great detailed post too- i recognize a bunch of potential offsets that we should be careful of....and ugh.

whoa- super timely blog post re. "equity offset: actions that are aligned with equity but are used as excuses to avoid deeper work and to continue being inequitable." equally true for nonprofits and academia.

love this framing! thank you for putting into (better, more organized) words what i tried to emphasize/define in my promotion file as "scholarship of engagement" love the idea of overlapping w/ own academic index, wish i would have come to this understanding earlier in my career!

yeah, no way that happens. i haven't seen evidence of growth mindset- just defensive posturing. and who is advising him?? i just can't believe he's learned so little from all this shit- it's been ongoing. it does give me some ideas re. the structural change we need though.

not to mention the "we couldn't find evidence of it in our records" part.... did they skip the on-line training modules we all do which stress believing and supporting the victim? jfc. it's disturbing.
i just reread it again. i am floored.
thanks to dr. borenstein and alice at  for providing free flu and hav shots to sep participants! 80% of our folks took them up on it! yay!

yeah-it's a buzz word for sure. we had a manager at a homeless shelter brag about being a harm reduction organization b/c they were "abstinence based" . ummmm ok??? so, we can give out sterile syringes then, right?

so, no power at cal poly- students working on grand unknowns in med micro- determined to see bacteria, so cell phone flashlight w/microscopes.... (the beeping alarms from incubators, freezers etc. anxiety provoking.
yay! (i don't have a book, just shouting out microbial ecology!)

good luck! i do 18-6, start eating at 1:30 or 2, have been for the last year. the first two weeks are not easy but it gets better. i feel much much more energetic, lost wt & w/keeping up my workouts, you can see a teeny muscle now and again. you can do it!
we are going to present (fingers crossed) on a program at the jail, and our efforts (still in progress) to involve participants more in our work...
no, but my sister (the real anthro stud) will be there! i will be at sfaa again this year though! i still say do it!
do it. no one will care, and you will be there to explain why it's way cooler.
the cutting stone. yes!

my extroverted kid is pissed off at my introverted kid for not accepting social invitations, and not wanting to sleep over (at anyone's house, ever). i swear, if the extrovert could just do all the socializing for all of us, we'd all be happier....
oh no, this is terrible and gross!! shame on them. i love that graphic, and order  mugs for all our graduating and moving on sep volunteers. https://www.iowaharmreductioncoalition.org/shop/
help support these amazing students share their research! physiological ecology of reptiles laboratory (perl)
and they kept having to duck under the doors everywhere...i love them all so much it hurts my heart....so sweet!
binge watching queer eye in japan w/my kids was *exactly* what i needed after this ridiculous ridiculous month....
the students will love it! tell them it's toddler version of a dendritic cell.... and way better than the coffee i spilled all over my stack last quarter. yikes.
me too....
yes! let's do it! i have a grant due usually on jan 31, but this is enough time to plan.
have i told you lately that i love you sandi?
can harm reduction finally take root in america’s schools?
gave med micro quiz w this cartoon....and my student is hilarious....
this is the stuff that keeps me up at night....and why we have to always balance between more outreach and keeping a low profile. ugh- it's so gross.

proud mamma moment: my middle schooler got two bonus points on science project for including + and - controls. when my husband pressed him re what they were, he said very off hand: "+ tells you the expt can work, - tells you if anything weird happened." duh, dad.

awww, thanks you are so sweet! and... for reals you're doing awesome! i'm so happy you came here! i just wish we had more time to hang out- it's too dang busy! hang in there- this is a tough time of the quarter for everyone!
a positive interaction with an undergraduate that solved their specific problem, decreased their future anxiety and is pretty easy to implement.
halloween shenanigans at the sep last night!
i loved this talk- i am going to share with my undergraduates!!
i subtweet with tedtalks....

"..inequities are embedded in political & economic organization of our social world, often in ways invisible to those w/ privilege and power; its impact-premature deaths, suffering, illness-is violent. we do little for our patients if we fail to recognize these social injustices.

".... i knew that epidemics emerge along the fissures of our society, reflecting not only biology, but more importantly patterns of marginalization, exclusion, discrimination related to race, gender, sexuality, class and more..."

why your doctor should care about social justice (mary bassett | tedmed 2015) https://www.ted.com/talks/mary_bassett_why_your_doctor_should_care_about_social_justice?utm_source=twitter.com&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=tedspread via
heading to chicago....giving talk about harm reduction... and spreading a little love, empathy, respect!

to be clear, in the same time span, we can document that sep participants have reversed 55 overdoses- and probably many more that go unreported. it's hard, scary work- and they deserve credit for it, plus our volunteers busting ass to get narcan out wherever and whenever we can!

tfw your community is in middle of an overdose crisis due to fentanyl (10 deaths since may) & ph officials interviewed on npr mainly ref narcan available at pharm. if not for our sep participants- death count would likely be *much* higher. no credit to them or to sep for work.

"fentanyl overdose deaths have skyrocketed in slo county since may, health officials warn" https://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/health-and-medicine/article236530263.html . free overdose prevention education and naloxone kits at sep wed. 5:30-8:30 feel free to dm me if this time doesn't work or if not comfortable coming in to sep.
random med micro poll: which superpower? fav answer=extract microplastics, most real=pay off student loans (runner up, work a microscope)
"most tested samples were found containing more than 90% of labeled naloxone, including those stored for nearly 30 years. "
was just talking about what to do w/ expired naloxone at the jail- hoping to be able to get back and give to programs that need....
love this one too! 5 badly informed opinions about vaccines http://www.thepharmafist.com/vaccines/ via
great start to a sunday....cello duet gig w this cute musician!

more helpful vaccination images! i love me some good nerd cartoons! vaccines work. here are the facts. https://thenib.com/vaccines-work-here-are-the-facts-5de3d0f9ffd0?utm_campaign=web-share-links&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter via
getting ready for a county health commission presentation on vaccines, this podcast was helpful framing! the anti-anti-vax-vaccine | crooked media

and-it's not just pdmps, it's arbitrary control over what & how much a person can get by insurance. know someone who gets 65 percos/yr(for years) for neuropathy, but insurance will only pay for vicodin, which don't work. it's just cruel. luckily they know heroin not safe now.

we had been considering providing less strips to save $, b/c they are a bit problematic (don't catch all analogs, & not quant)-but decided based on feedback from participants to keep available- some folks really want to know. it's a blunt tool, is all- which we tell them.

our numbers at sep in ca are pretty similar (no stats yet) but we have about 60% using strips, 50% drugs testing positive for fent, and 38% report behavior change (using less most common)- and our folks really like having the strips available.
no, but i do now! and you too, thanks! that sounds like exactly what we need.

yes! we need to think creatively like that-those are all great ideas! we also suffer from lack of trust, they don't trust us b/c stigma, & we don't trust them b/c punitive or paternalistic. but, in a small victory, we did get the county to purchase us a secure sharps container.

so tired. slo bangers is teeeny cbo-sep.folks want to collaborate w us bc access to people using drugs makes them look good during overdose crisis. but then want mou, policy & procedures, summary reports, presentations. gah! how to have time to actually do the work & stay funded?
used med micro students to crowd source ideas for health commision talk debunking mythology around vaccines! so many great points.... my students!!
now sitting in 12yo's cello lesson, trying to grade quizzes listening to him bravely tackle bach's arioso. my kids blow me away...

my 15 yo is doing his ap euro homework and blasting bach's double concerto so loud on his earphones i can hear it across the room....i find it endearing, but i can't tell him that so....tweeting my feelings....
cal poly- slo  has a basic needs initiative, one of my former students (woot! bio dept!) was the americorp vista spearheading a lot of the outreach and education. here's the resource page link:
love this and totally stealing.... i'm feeling a tcr signal transduction pathway, and complement cascade deserve chalk art....

from slo bangers sep site manager: "there’s still really bad shit in slo, two of our guys died this past week really sad. our peeps are really scared. it makes me so sad and mad." be careful out there slo folks.

took 3 undergrads to a conference last week. as always, i told them to let their faculty know ahead, & i could back up if needed. one faculty is giving *me* grief for not providing documentation ahead of time-wtf?? i just trust my students when they tell me what they're doing!
taco temple!!!!!!!!! :-)
i made letterhead today! this seems like a small thing, but.... it made me happy.

happy to share- it was the best session!! feel free to dm me if you want to chat more! one last quote i wrote down (so sorry i did not catch panelists names to give credit) to academics w/ less experience "people don't care how much you know, unless they know how much you care"

finally, different session (budgeting for ssp with  ) gave great ideas about how to effectively write positions into grants & have flexibility too-we have only one part time site manager now, but really want to bring in participants' voices and pay/employ them.

4. value folks voices, connections and experience with money. also, think about things that might be triggering or difficult for folks and have conversations about where to set boundries (ex. working with le)

3. training! training everyone (anti-stigma, anti-racist, how to be a respectful human) for folks on site that don’t have lived experience is paramount too. try to plan so person you hire is not set up to fail- rigid hours/shifts, having flexible or overlapping coverage.

2. short term or one time cash (or visa card) payouts like incentives have their place, but *way* better to plan to pay folks a real wage for work they do, with a real title, and think about how to train them for transferrable skills (phlebotomy, testing etc)
